What are extensions?

Extensions are small software programs that customize the browsing experience. They enable users to tailor Chrome functionality and behavior to individual needs or preferences. They are built on web technologies such as HTML, JavaScript, and CSS.

An extension must fulfill a single purpose that is narrowly defined and easy to understand. It can include multiple components if they contribute to their extensions underlying intention.

User interfaces can range from a simple icon, such as the Google Mail Checker extension shown on the right, to overriding an entire page.

Extensions files are zipped into a single .crx package that the user downloads and installs. This means extensions do not depend on content from the web, unlike ordinary web apps.

Extensions are distributed through the Chrome Developer Dashboard and publish to the Chrome Web Store. For more information, see the store developer documentation.

How do I start?

  1. Follow the Getting Started tutorial
  2. Read the Overview
  3. Keep up to date by reading the Chromium blog
  4. Subscribe to the chromium-extensions group
